book_name: An Elegant Puzzle - Systems of Engineering Management - by Will Larson.pdf
summary: In this chapter, the author explores two different approaches to implementing change within teams: the top-down mandate and the Model, Document, Share method. The latter emphasizes gradual adoption, allowing teams the agency to choose practices that work best for them. This approach encourages documentation and sharing of successful methods without pressuring others to conform. The author notes that while this method can lead to organic adoption, it is not without its failures. Ultimately, the effectiveness of the approach depends on the alignment with organizational values and the circumstances at play.

slides.section_body: Documenting your approach allows for clarity and shared understanding across the team. Providing detailed information ensures that practices are not just personal but can be accessed and refined by others. This foundational step is vital in effectively rolling out new methods.
slides.quote: Be as detailed as possible: make a canonical document.

slides.section_body: Sharing experiences and documentation creates an open environment for learning and improvement. Instead of pushing others to adopt changes, simply presenting your method encourages organic interest and exploration. Less pressure often leads to greater results.
slides.quote: Just present the approach and your experience following it.

slides.section_body: Focus on refining practices that work effectively for your team rather than spending excessive time convincing others. The emphasis should be on gradual improvement and adaptation instead of enforcing quick compliance. This promotes a culture of understanding.
slides.quote: You’ll spend the majority of your time refining approaches that work effectively.

slides.section_title: Top-Down Mandate vs. Model, Document, Share
slides.section_body: Top-down mandates operate on the premise that quick adoption of mediocre methods is preferable. In contrast, the Model, Document, Share approach champions the thorough and thoughtful adoption of superior practices at a sustainable pace.
slides.quote: Mandates assume: It’s better to adopt a good-enough approach quickly.

slides.section_body: The Model, Document, Share approach shifts decision-making power from central authorities to individual teams. This decentralized method recognizes that teams have unique contexts and can better assess their own needs for adapting practices.
slides.quote: Teams have agency to adopt the appropriate practices for themselves.

slides.section_body: This approach permits a gradual evolution toward better practices, allowing teams to synchronize and improve at their own pace. It respects the natural progression of team dynamics, fostering readiness and confidence in change.
slides.quote: It’s okay to approach change gradually.

slides.section_body: For the Model, Document, Share method to work effectively, some degree of natural authority is necessary. Earning the respect of peers can enhance the chances of successful adoption without needing formal power to enforce change.
slides.quote: You’ll still need some natural authority, the respect of your peers.

slides.section_body: Not every context will benefit from this decentralized approach. Understanding when it fails is crucial; sometimes, it might not gain traction, leading to unfulfilled goals. Awareness of this limitation is key for effective leadership.
slides.quote: I’ve also seen this approach go nowhere.

slides.section_body: Attempting to circumvent organizational authority using this method typically leads to negative outcomes. Successful implementation requires navigating the existing structure and presenting alternative practices without direct confrontation.
slides.quote: Operating in direct conflict with authority usually doesn’t end very well.

slides.section_body: Ultimately, the success of the Model, Document, Share approach depends on its alignment with organizational values and circumstances. Ensuring that these elements are in sync can lead to a more effective and meaningful change process.
slides.quote: If your circumstances and your organization’s values align with the second list, then this approach may be more effective.
